moves.4. Qe3 Nf6 5. f3: Maybe it was better to avoid weakening the kingside and to defend the pawn with Nc3 or Bd3. This has the added bonus of developing.
moves.5... Be7 6. c3: Falling further behind in development. This square belongs to the knight.
moves.6... O-O 7. g3: Still refusing to develop, and this will prove diastrous if black manages to open up the game quickly, which I did.
moves.7... Re8: Creating the threat of d5. The queen and king being on the same file allows some tactical ideas.
moves.8. Bh3: Finally developing a piece, but it may already be too late.
moves.8... d5 9. e5: Falling for the trick. Nd2 trying to holsd the pawn would have been better.
moves.9... Nxe5: Due to the potential king and queen pin, the knight shouldnt be taken.
moves.10. Bxc8 Qxc8 11. Ne2: After the tactical skirmish, black is only a pawn up, but his supeior development and the activity of the pieces virtually guarantee a win.
moves.11... Nc4 12. Qd3 Bc5: Preventing the king from castling as well as eying up some some nice squares in the white camp.
moves.14. Bxe3 Rxe3 15. Qd2 Qe6: White cant castle as the knight on e2 will fall.
moves.16. Nc2: Trying to force the rook away.
moves.16... Re5 17. f4 Re4: But it still has this square where it cant be touched.
moves.18. h3: White has been reduced to total passiveness, and black has as much time as he wants to try and finish the game off.
moves.21. Rxe2 Qxe2 22. Qxd5 Be3+ 23. Nxe3 Qxe: Black still has to be careful as swapping the queens with Qe4  allows Qxe4 and Rd8, mating.
moves.26... Qc1+: This tactic swaps queens without allowing a mate.
moves.27. Rxc1 Rxd8 28. Kc2: The rest of the game is fairly easy, and there is no need for annotation.
